billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO CIVIL SERVICE AND PENSIONS

title: Repeals provisions mandating payroll deductions from public employees who engage in prohibited strikes
summary: Repeals provisions mandating a payroll deduction at twice the daily rate of pay for each day a public employee engages in an illegal strike.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2570

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to repeal paragraph (f) of subdivision 2 of section 210 of the
civil service law, relating to the prohibition of strikes by public
employees and individual penalties

SUMMARY:
This bill repeals the penalty of two days pay for each day a public
employee participates in a strike.

JUSTIFICATION:
Enactment of this bill would remove from the Taylor Law the excessively
punitive penalty of the loss of the second day's pay for each day of a
strike. The bill would NOT repeal the prohibition of strikes. Public
employee strikes will continue to be penalties for striking. In addition
to loss of the second day's pay for each day of a strike, state law
includes the following provisions: fines and imprisonment imposed by the
courts upon individuals (judiciary Law, Section 751, subdivision 2)
-removal or other disciplinary action against individuals (Civil Service
Law, Section 210, subdivision 2) -loss of payroll deduction of dues by
the employee organization (Civil Service Law, Section 210, subdivision
3) None.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
